week we attempted to point out that the abolition of football
LAST
would in no way aid any program of physical education. We also
are of the firm conviction that if football were abolished, all other
intercollegiate sports would shortly have to be discontinued. If football were abolished at Hopkins, other sports would have to be supported by lacrosse. Up to the present, Hopkins has always had good
lacrosse teams, and has played teams representing institutions of a high
scholastic standing. There have been few protests against lacrosse.
Lacrosse is now rapidly gaining favor throughout the East. It is a
game that holds the interest of the spectator throughout. The bodily
contact that draws the crowd to football is also present in this game.
It is reasonable to suppose that in the future it will replace the relatively slower game of baseball and become the major spring sport.
Hopkins has held its high position in lacrossee in the past because
of the skill of its players, and their knowledge of the game due to
excellent coaching. During the last several years, Hopkins has retained its position with difficulty, as with an increase in interest in
the sport, other institutions are employing better coaches and finding
more experienced men among their enrollment. When these institutions have teams that can compete with Hopkins in skill and knowledge of the game, they will consistently win if they have better natural
athletes.
The abolition of football will bring about this situation. In the
present freshman class, there are a considerable number of foot-ball
mandidates who may be expected to be good lacrosse players. There
are a certain number of these men who would not attend Hopkins if
football is abolished. Because of the emphasis puaced on football,
nearly all good athlets are primarily interested in this game. For the
first time during the past three years, Hopkins has some good athletes
among its first year men. A relatively good football team may be expected next year. If football were abolished, these men would attend
other institutions. Lacrosse would suffer nearly as much as football,
and with the decay of lacrosse, all other inter-collegiate sports would
have to be abolished.
Some of those who favor the abolition of football, also favor the
abolition of all inter-collegiate sports, but it would be well for those
who wish to drop only football because of the poor teams developed,
to consider the effect this would have on other sports.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
Dear Sir:
I am a member of the Freshman
Class, and so the late-lamented
mid-year's were the first exams I
have ever encountered. The exams,
themselves, were much as I expected, but the method of marking
was, in my opinion, and in most
other peoples', decidedly erratic.
And since, after all, marks are the
only visible results of a half-year's
work, to which we can refer, it certainly seems that the administration
has introduced a faulty system,
where only an absolutely perfect
one should be used.
There should be a standard that
would be prevalent all over the college. With the present H, S and F
method, no such standard exists. It
has been my experience to hear two
teachers express far different opinions as to how these marks should
be given. One told me that there
was a definite numerical number
which separates the wheat from the
chaff—the H's from the S's and
from the F's. Then another quite
heatedly stated that the standard
lies entirely in the teacher's sense
of discretion—which, if one can go
by results, are decidedly varied. An
H with one professor will probably
be an S with another.
Now, I, in company with a host
of others, am aiming for entry into
the Medical School. It seems to me
marks are the most important thing
upon which entry can be based.
Also, scholarships and grants are
based upon them—with the exception of those given athletes, of
course. The question naturally
arises in anyone's mind as to how
anything can be based on a host of
ambiguous H, S and F's. A mere
shade of difference can distinguish
between an honor student, and one
who is merely satisfactory. And
that shade would probably depend
upon the idiosyncrasies of the various profs. Thus, a man whose
teachers worked upon the numerical basis, would and does in practically every case, receive a grade
superior to that of the man who
must depend on his teacher's sense
of discretion, and what with these
kid instructors, there are many
teachers who have not even reached
the age of discretion.
Thus, it is my opinion, a return
to the numerical system should be
immediately affected, and I believe
that hundreds of others agree with
Yours truly,
me.

week we attempted to point out that the abolition of football

would in no way aid any program of physical education. We also
are of the firm conviction that if football were abolished, all other
intercollegiate sports would shortly have to be discontinued. If football were abolished at Hopkins, other sports would have to be supported by lacrosse. Up to the present, Hopkins has always had good
lacrosse teams, and has played teams representing institutions of a high
scholastic standing. There have been few protests against lacrosse.
Lacrosse is now rapidly gaining favor throughout the East. It is a
game that holds the interest of the spectator throughout. The bodily
contact that draws the crowd to football is also present in this game.
It is reasonable to suppose that in the future it will replace the relatively slower game of baseball and become the major spring sport.
Hopkins has held its high position in lacrossee in the past because
of the skill of its players, and their knowledge of the game due to
excellent coaching. During the last several years, Hopkins has retained its position with difficulty, as with an increase in interest in
the sport, other institutions are employing better coaches and finding
more experienced men among their enrollment. When these institutions have teams that can compete with Hopkins in skill and knowledge of the game, they will consistently win if they have better natural
athletes.
The abolition of football will bring about this situation. In the
present freshman class, there are a considerable number of foot-ball
mandidates who may be expected to be good lacrosse players. There
are a certain number of these men who would not attend Hopkins if
football is abolished. Because of the emphasis puaced on football,
nearly all good athlets are primarily interested in this game. For the
first time during the past three years, Hopkins has some good athletes
among its first year men. A relatively good football team may be expected next year. If football were abolished, these men would attend
other institutions. Lacrosse would suffer nearly as much as football,
and with the decay of lacrosse, all other inter-collegiate sports would
have to be abolished.
Some of those who favor the abolition of football, also favor the
abolition of all inter-collegiate sports, but it would be well for those
who wish to drop only football because of the poor teams developed,
to consider the effect this would have on other sports.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
Dear Sir:
I am a member of the Freshman
Class, and so the late-lamented
mid-year's were the first exams I
have ever encountered. The exams,
themselves, were much as I expected, but the method of marking
was, in my opinion, and in most
other peoples', decidedly erratic.
And since, after all, marks are the
only visible results of a half-year's
work, to which we can refer, it certainly seems that the administration
has introduced a faulty system,
where only an absolutely perfect
one should be used.
There should be a standard that
would be prevalent all over the college. With the present H, S and F
method, no such standard exists. It
has been my experience to hear two
teachers express far different opinions as to how these marks should
be given. One told me that there
was a definite numerical number
which separates the wheat from the
chaff—the H's from the S's and
from the F's. Then another quite
heatedly stated that the standard
lies entirely in the teacher's sense
of discretion—which, if one can go
by results, are decidedly varied. An
H with one professor will probably
be an S with another.
Now, I, in company with a host
of others, am aiming for entry into
the Medical School. It seems to me
marks are the most important thing
upon which entry can be based.
Also, scholarships and grants are
based upon them—with the exception of those given athletes, of
course. The question naturally
arises in anyone's mind as to how
anything can be based on a host of
ambiguous H, S and F's. A mere
shade of difference can distinguish
between an honor student, and one
who is merely satisfactory. And
that shade would probably depend
upon the idiosyncrasies of the various profs. Thus, a man whose
teachers worked upon the numerical basis, would and does in practically every case, receive a grade
superior to that of the man who
must depend on his teacher's sense
of discretion, and what with these
kid instructors, there are many
teachers who have not even reached
the age of discretion.
Thus, it is my opinion, a return
to the numerical system should be
immediately affected, and I believe
that hundreds of others agree with
Yours truly,
me.
